- Dealers who simply name a brand risk missing the opportunity to build trust with the farmer.
- Instead, dealers should focus on emphasizing their service and support capabilities, such as:
  - Availability of parts and service technicians
  - Average repair time and uptime statistics for their customers
  - Warranty and maintenance programs offered
- The goal is to demonstrate the dealer's commitment to the farmer's success, not just sell a product.
- Providing this kind of transparent, service-focused response can help build long-term trust and loyalty with farm customers.

items.title: College of Agriculture and Life Sciences formalizes student advising standard of care
items.description: Student-centered academic advising framework emphasizes mentorship and personalized support The post College of Agriculture and Life Sciences formalizes student advising standard of care appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences has formalized a student advising standard of care to strengthen student success and support advisor well-being. The new framework, developed by the College's director of advising, Jennifer Rhinesmith-Carranza, Ph.D., emphasizes mentorship, personalized support, and a student-centered approach. 

The standard of care highlights 7 focus areas, including clear communication, individualized guidance, authenticity, and a growth-focused mindset. It aims to help advisors connect students with campus resources, navigate degree requirements, and provide a clear next step for students.

In 2025, the College's advising team won several awards, including the President's Meritorious Service Award for individual and supervisor contributions, the President's Award for Academic Advising, the New Advisor Award, the Excellence in Graduate Advising Award, and the Dean's Outstanding Achievement Award for staff excellence.

The formalization of this standard of care reinforces the College's culture of continuous learning and reflects the human side of advising, emphasizing meaningful relationships, long-term goal support, and student empowerment. This latest step aims to strengthen the student experience and position the College as a leader in advising practice.

items.title: Is sulfur a mobile nutrient? Carryover, soybean needs, and S fertilizer product differences
items.summary:
Key points:

- Research funded by AFREC and Minnesota Soybean shows that applying 10 lbs of sulfate per acre for 4 years resulted in sulfur carryover for at least 2 more years, meeting corn's sulfur needs. This can explain lack of sulfur responses in research around 2015, as carryover was sufficient.

- Soybeans do need sulfur, but direct application may not always benefit yield. In 2 out of 30 trials, sulfur increased soybean yield, usually when there was no carryover from prior applications. 

- Applying 20 lbs of sulfur per acre, regardless of source, ahead of corn in a corn-soybean rotation benefited both crops. Soybean benefits from sulfur applied to the prior corn crop.

- For sulfate application timing, spring is best for crops with high sulfur demand like corn, alfalfa, and canola. Fall application of sulfate can work on medium-fine soils, but elemental S products like Tiger-Sul may need 5-6 years to fully oxidize.

- Recommendations: Avoid immediately incorporating elemental S or S-bentonite products; allow 2+ weeks before incorporation. Consider adding a sulfate or thiosulfate source for a few years until prior S applications become available.

The research was funded by AFREC and the Minnesota Soybean Research and Promotion Council.

items.title: MN CropCast: Unlocking the soybean genome with Dr. Bob Stupar
items.summary:
Key points:

- Dr. Bob Stupar, Professor of Agronomy and Plant Genetics at the University of Minnesota, was interviewed on the Minnesota CropCast podcast (Episode #57) about unlocking the soybean genome.

- Dr. Stupar discussed the critical process of identifying genes of interest, validating their functionality, and engineering soybeans to possess important, novel traits.

- He highlighted the importance of maintaining and updating reference genomes - the essential "blueprints" for scientific advancement. 

- Gene editing is being used to improve soybean quality traits, such as reducing antinutritional components.

- Dr. Stupar's proudest contribution is graduate student training and workforce development, ensuring the next generation of scientists is ready to lead.

items.title: Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions
items.description: Since 2018, the entrepreneurial couple has benefited from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which they‚Äôve used to support themselves and their children, and to keep the business running. As small business owners who strive to offer good-paying jobs to their employees and give back to the community as much as possible, they don’t have […] The post Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Since 2018, an entrepreneurial couple has been using SNAP benefits to support their family and keep their small business running. However, several states have recently introduced new SNAP restrictions, causing confusion and disruption.

The new SNAP rules limit the types of food that can be purchased using the benefits. This has created more chaos for small business owners who rely on SNAP customers, as they struggle to navigate the changing regulations.

Experts warn that these SNAP restrictions could have significant impacts on farmers and small food businesses. There are concerns that the changes will reduce access to healthy food options for low-income families and negatively affect the livelihoods of small-scale producers.

The article does not provide specific numbers, statistics, or expert quotes. However, it highlights the broader context of the issue and the potential consequences for farmers and small business owners who rely on SNAP customers.

There are no clear recommendations or action items provided in the article. The main message is the confusion and disruption caused by the new SNAP restrictions at the state level, and the need for more clarity and support for affected small businesses and farmers.

items.title: Improving waterhemp control by managing spray water pH
items.summary:
The study conducted in Rochester, Minnesota in 2025 evaluated how spray water pH adjustment and timing of spray solution mixing affected waterhemp control in a corn herbicide program. 

The treatments included a tank mix of atrazine and Acuron GT (at full or half rate) with NIS and AMS, with or without a pH-lowering and buffering adjuvant (AlpHa Shot), and mixed either six days prior to application or at the time of spraying.

Adding the pH-lowering adjuvant reduced spray water pH from 7.5 to 5.8, which improved waterhemp control by 10% at 24 days after treatment (DAT) and 7% at 112 DAT. Waterhemp density decreased by 64% and biomass was reduced by 55% in treatments with the pH adjuster.

The timing of mixing the pH adjuster (6 days ahead or at time of spraying) did not affect waterhemp control, density, or biomass. The improved weed control was observed at both full and half rates of Acuron GT.

The key takeaway is that conditioning the spray water to the proper pH can improve herbicide performance and season-long waterhemp management, regardless of when the solution is mixed. Testing water pH and using a water conditioner or buffering agent is recommended if waterhemp control has been inconsistent.

The study was conducted by Eric Yu and Ryan Miller, UMN Extension Crops Educators, and was published on February 17, 2026 in the UMN Crop News.

items.title: 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February
items.description: Most farmers plant cover crops in the fall, and let the winter terminate them before they go to seed. But you can still plant cover crops in winter, as long as you know which will work in your climate. Plant these five cover crops this month for early spring benefits. The post 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Requires soil temperature of at least 40¬∞F (4¬∞C).

Kale - A multipurpose cover crop that feeds the soil, farmer, customers, and livestock. Needs slightly warmer soil of at least 45¬∞F (7¬∞C). Certain varieties are specialty market items.

Daikon Radish - Also called forage radish, the long taproots reach deep into the soil to break up compaction and scavenge leftover nitrogen. Requires soil temperature of at least 65¬∞F (18¬∞C).

Oats - Grow quickly to prevent weed germination. Form beneficial relationships with fungi. Sow at a rate of 4-6 oz per 100 sq ft. Can be terminated without harvesting oats.

Buckwheat - A quick-maturing phosphorus scavenger that conditions poor soils. Attracts pollinators and beneficial insects. Can be used as an organic mulch.

The article notes that low tunnels can provide extra warmth and protection for cover crops in colder climates. Planting cover crops before spring can lead to economic benefits for farms through improved soil health, carbon sequestration, and erosion prevention.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops! session talked forecasting tools for crop and pest management
items.summary:
The webinar series runs through March and is still open for registration.

Key points:
- Cold weather impacts on overwintering insect pests like soybean aphid, corn rootworm, and alfalfa weevil. Colder temperatures (below 0¬∞F) can lead to 50-95% mortality for some pests.
- Forecasting tools like pheromone traps and degree day calculations can help predict arrival and development of migratory pests like black cutworm, potato leafhopper, and corn earworm.
- Crop disease forecasting tools like the ipmPIPE website track the spread of diseases like southern rust of corn and tar spot.
- The expanding Minnesota Ag Weather Network provides hyperlocal weather data and degree day models for various crops and pests.
- The North Dakota Ag Weather Network (NDAWN) hosts many of these forecasting tools, including models for sugarbeet root maggot, wheat midge, Cercospora leaf spot, white mold, and Fusarium head blight.
- Scouting fields is still important to validate the forecasting tools.

The article emphasizes how these advanced forecasting tools can help Minnesota farmers better time management practices and prepare for crop and pest threats.

items.title: Help the Crops Team fine-tune programming!
items.summary:
The University of Minnesota Extension Crops Team is conducting a survey to better understand the educational needs and preferences of row crop and forage producers, as well as agriculture professionals who work with them. The goal is to customize their educational programs to the interests of these stakeholders.

The survey is anonymous and takes 12-15 minutes to complete. It aims to gather information about participants' operations, learning preferences, and how they want to engage with Extension. The Crops Team wants to use the survey responses to develop and deliver programming that meets the needs of producers and professionals.

The survey is open until February 16, 2026. All row crop and forage producers, as well as crop consultants, seed salespeople, pesticide applicators, grain buyers, and other agriculture professionals, are encouraged to participate. Their input will help the Crops Team refine their programming to ensure it is useful and relevant.

items.title: Freeze, Thaw, Seed: Timing Pasture Renovation in an Unpredictable Winter
items.description: This winter‚Äôs erratic weather, swinging from ‚Äì30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm temperatures in the 50s, has left many wanting spring and ready to get back in the fields. Even though the groundhog predicted six more weeks of winter, temperatures have been trending upward. Over the next week, highs are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night. These natural freeze‚Äìthaw cycles signal the slow transition into spring.
items.summary:
Main news/finding: Erratic winter weather with extreme temperature swings presents an opportunity for farmers to thicken forage stands through frost seeding.

Key numbers/statistics:
- Highs expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night over the next week.
- Frost seeding can be a cost-effective way to rejuvenate a declining stand or introduce new legumes.

Dates/deadlines: None mentioned.

People/organizations/programs:
- Shelby Gruss, Assistant Professor Forage Extension Specialist at Iowa State University
- Iowa State University Extension and Outreach

Locations: Iowa

Context/causes: The unpredictable winter weather, swinging from extreme cold to unseasonably warm temperatures, is creating conditions suitable for frost seeding.

Impacts for farmers: Frost seeding can be used to thicken forage stands and introduce new legumes, which can help rejuvenate declining pastures in a cost-effective way.

Recommendations/action items:
- Farmers should consider frost seeding to take advantage of the current freeze-thaw cycle.
- For more information on best practices for frost seeding, review the "Frosting Seeding Legumes" article.

Expert quote:
"Her research focuses on optimizing forage-based systems through strategies to enhance resilience and productivity in annual and perennial forage through different management strategies. Current research projects focus on diversification, whether it be in a rotation with cover crops, intercropping for forage establishment, or utilizing different species to help break disease cycles."

items.title: Frosting Seeding Legumes
items.description: Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, such as red clover, into a tired pasture or within a small grain stand. It is a potentially cost-effective solution to revitalize a diminishing stand or introduce legumes to an existing forage stand. Frost seeding is usually not recommended with grass species. The success of frost seeding hinges upon assessing the condition of the existing stand and seeding at the proper time.
items.summary:
It is a cost-effective way to revitalize a diminishing forage stand or introduce legumes. Timing is critical, with frost seeding typically done between mid-February and early March to take advantage of freeze-thaw cycles that help incorporate the seed. 

A thick thatch can hinder success, so it's recommended to hay or overgraze the area in the prior fall/winter to open up the canopy. Sandy or very dry soils are less ideal, with loam or clay soils preferred. Adequate spring moisture is vital for establishing a healthy stand after frost seeding.

The article was authored by Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist at Iowa State University who joined the department in November 2023. Her research focuses on optimizing forage systems through strategies like diversification, cover cropping, and disease management.

items.title: All Day Ag Outlook Conference March 3 at the Beef House
items.description: The 36th annual All Day Ag Outlook will be held Tuesday, March 3, at the Beef House in Covington, Indiana. Join the WILLAg analysts and the farmdoc team for the day. items.title: 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February
items.description: It takes a lot to get the farm ready for the growing season. It all begins with the task of gathering together and starting vegetable seeds. February is an ideal time to get many of your spring crops going. Consider these 7 vegetables as you prepare your rows. The post 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
This can be done in protected environments like greenhouses, cold frames, or even in the home. Key vegetables to start from seed in February include:

- Slow-growing herbs like basil, oregano, and rosemary, which can take 1-4 weeks to germinate.
- Tomatoes, which need 80+ days from seed to fruit and do best with a heat mat. Opt for determinate varieties in short seasons.
- Peppers, which can take up to a month to sprout and need 2+ months to mature. Jalape√±o, serrano, and shishito are good productive options.
- Brassicas like broccoli, cabbage, and kale, which thrive in cool spring weather. Faster-maturing Asian brassicas work well in warm climates.
- Lettuces, which grow quickly and can handle some late frost. Both leaf and heading lettuces can be sown.
- Carrots and parsnips, which need to be direct sown in their final location due to sensitive taproots.
- Onions and leeks, which take 1-2 weeks to sprout and 75-140 days to mature.

The article recommends using protected growing environments like greenhouses, cold frames, and low/high tunnels to extend the growing season, especially in cold climates. Proper seed starting, potting up, and fertilizing are also key for success.

items.title: Feb 06 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: We had another cold and mostly dry week across the state. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the high 20s in southern Illinois, between 8 and 18 degrees below average. A healthy snowpack in the southern half of the state helped push nighttime low temperatures well below 0, including lows of 7 below in Taylorville and 4 below in Jerseyville. The cold end to January pushed the month as a whole to be around 2 degrees below normal statewide.…
items.summary:
Temperatures this past week were 8-18 degrees below average, with lows reaching -7¬∞F in Taylorville and -4¬∞F in Jerseyville. January as a whole was about 2 degrees below normal statewide. Precipitation was scarce, with most areas receiving less than 0.1 inches of light snow. January ended around 2 inches drier than normal statewide. While some areas like Du Quoin had over 20 inches of snow, it only yielded less than 1 inch of liquid water, providing little drought relief.  

Looking ahead, temperatures are expected to warm up to the 40s and 50s next week, but precipitation will remain sparse at under 0.1 inches. The third week of February is forecasted to be warmer and wetter than average as a more active weather pattern moves in. 

The article also features comments from experts on the importance of using the N-Rate Calculator and Precision Conservation Management program to maximize profits rather than just yields. These tools help farmers optimize nitrogen applications to protect local water quality while maintaining their bottom line.

The article mentions the weekly WILLAg.org radio programming, including the Commodity Week and Closing Market Report podcasts.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary: Farmers are using new search methods like AI-assisted tools, voice search, and quick-scan platforms that often provide answers without requiring a click. As a result, attention metrics like time spent, scroll depth, and ad viewability are now more important indicators of advertising effectiveness. Experts recommend that agricultural advertisers focus on maximizing attention and engagement rather than just clicks and conversions. This shift is driven by changes in farmer search behavior, with AI and voice search reducing the need for direct clicks. Advertisers need to adapt their strategies to this new landscape in order to effectively reach and connect with their farmer audience.

items.title: Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction Recent dust storm events in central Illinois and across the Midwest have renewed attention on soil conservation, especially after the tragic May 2023 event near Springfield that caused an 80-vehicle pileup, eight fatalities, and dozens of injuries. These incidents highlight that soil loss is not only an agronomic issue but also a public safety and environmental concern. Reduced tillage and cover crops are well-established pract
items.summary:
Key Findings:
- Field trials were conducted in 2024-2025 at 6 sites in central Illinois and north-central Iowa to evaluate soybean performance under different tillage (conventional, strip-till, no-till) and cover crop (no cover, cereal rye) systems.
- Starter fertilizer (15 lb N/ac or 15 lb N/ac + 10 lb S/ac) was evaluated in each system.
- Soybeans showed an early-season response to starter fertilizer, with increased biomass at V4 stage. However, this did not translate to higher yields.
- Soybean yields ranged from 60-95 bu/ac across trials. Yields were similar across tillage/cover crop systems, with conventional tillage and strip-till averaging 78.4 bu/ac, no-till at 77.6 bu/ac, and no-till with cereal rye at 76.2 bu/ac. 
- While yields were comparable, differences in profitability emerged due to varying input costs. No-till had the highest partial net return, followed by strip-till and conventional tillage. No-till with cereal rye had the lowest partial net return due to cover crop management costs.
- The study will continue in 2026 to track longer-term impacts on soil, residue, and nutrient dynamics in conservation systems.

items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Greenhouses trap thermal heat to warm plants, with some featuring vents, irrigation systems, and climate controls. Different types of greenhouses include modular plastic, low tunnels, cold frames, and designer greenhouses with concrete foundations and climate controls. 

For February greenhouse growing, good options include:
- Tomatoes and peppers, which benefit from early planting to give their long germination time
- Brassicas like kale, cabbage, cauliflower, and broccoli to get an early harvest before spring pests arrive
- Lettuces, which can be grown as baby greens or full-sized heads
- Potatoes, to get full-sized tubers or baby potatoes by spring
- Onions, including sets, seeds, and bunching onions
- Flowers like lisianthus, coneflowers, and dahlias that take a long time to sprout

Proper greenhouse setup is key, with considerations around heat, ventilation, lighting, and pest protection. Greenhouses can raise temperatures by 2-30¬∞F compared to outside, depending on the design.

The article does not provide any specific dates, prices, or expert quotes. It focuses on the general principles and recommended crops for February greenhouse growing across different regions and greenhouse types.

items.title: Farm Journal and Hass Avocado Board Launch The Avocado Conference
items.description: Kansas City, MO., (January 28, 2026) ‚Äì  The Packer, the produce industry‚Äôs premier publication from Farm Journal, announced the launch of The Avocado Conference, a first-of-its-kind international event gathering every segment of the U.S. avocado supply chain. The inaugural event is set for Nov. 18-20, 2026, at the Hilton San Diego Bayfront. The conference directly […] The post Farm Journal and Hass Avocado Board Launch The Avocado Conference appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
S. avocado supply chain. The inaugural 3-day conference will be held on November 18-20, 2026 at the Hilton San Diego Bayfront. 

The conference aims to bring together every segment of the avocado industry - including producers, exporters, importers, packers, retail and foodservice buyers - to collaborate, share data-driven insights, and align on strategies to strengthen the avocado category. Sessions will cover global avocado production and trade, retail/foodservice market trends, consumer insights, marketing programs, economic factors, and Hass Avocado Board's initiatives to expand avocado demand.

The Hass Avocado Board, which is supporting the conference content, sees it as a unique platform to unite the industry and accelerate sustainable growth in U.S. avocado consumption. The event is being organized by Farm Journal, the nation's leading agricultural media company, in collaboration with the Hass Avocado Board.

items.title: New Training Materials Available for Iowa Pesticide Applicators
items.description: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on Jan. 1.
items.summary: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on January 1, 2026. The updated training manuals, including the Iowa Core Manual (CS445) and the Private Pesticide Applicator Manual (CS1), are available through the ISU Extension Store. New exams based on the revised core manual are also available at all Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship test sites. The Private Pesticide Applicator Manual now includes a two-page informational update, and all private exams now include content from this insert. Farmers can contact Betsy Danielson, the Pesticide Safety Education Extension Specialist, for more information at betsydan@iastate.edu.

items.title: Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer.
items.description: Lead generation starts with delivering real value in exchange for a farmer‚Äôs time and attention. The CTA and offer you choose shape not only how many leads you capture, but how qualified, motivated and purchase-ready those prospects become. When you shift your mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need in […] The post Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer. appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary: Lead generation should focus on delivering real value in exchange for a farmer's time and attention. The choice of call-to-action (CTA) and offer shapes not only the number of leads captured, but also their quality, motivation, and purchase-readiness. The article encourages shifting the mindset from what the business wants to collect to what farmers genuinely need.

items.title: Jan 23 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: Winter has come back with a vengeance after a temporary pause. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the mid-20s in southern Illinois, between 4 and 8 degrees below normal statewide. Nighttime low temperatures this week regularly dipped into the single digits, if not below zero, including -5 degrees in Rockford and -2 in Aurora. The wind was also a factor, pushing wind chill values close to -20 on a few days.…
items.summary:
Over the past week, temperatures were 4-8 degrees below normal across the state, with nighttime lows reaching as low as -5¬∞F in Rockford and -2¬∞F in Aurora. The cold weather was accompanied by strong winds, resulting in wind chill values close to -20¬∞F on some days. 

Precipitation levels were also low, with 7-day totals ranging from around 0.5 inches in northeast Illinois to virtually nothing in southwest Illinois. January to date has been very dry, with Carbondale and Charleston experiencing the 4th and 10th driest first two-thirds of January on record, respectively, both receiving less than 0.5 inches of precipitation.

The cold temperatures are expected to persist for at least another week, with most of the northern half of the state likely to remain below freezing for the rest of the month. However, a strong winter storm is projected to bring significant snowfall, with central Illinois expected to receive 3-4 inches and southern Illinois potentially seeing 8-12 inches, with isolated pockets of heavier snow.

The article also includes information about the "Commodity Week" radio program, which features commodity market analysis from experts Chip Nellinger of Blue Reef Agri-Marketing, Brian Stark from The Andersons, and Arlan Suderman with StoneX.

items.title: Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing
items.description: The world is searching for information a bit differently these days. Gone are the days of winning the click (traditional SEO). The game now is centered on winning brand authority and trust (modern AEO, answer engine optimization). In a world now crowded with ‚ÄúAI slop,‚Äù brands will only cut through by growing brand authority and […] The post Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Some key points:

- Traditional SEO (search engine optimization) focused on winning the click, but the new focus is on winning brand authority and trust through AEO.

- Farmers are increasingly turning to AI-powered platforms like ChatGPT and Google's AI Overviews for instant answers, rather than traditional search engines. Brands need to be present in these new discovery channels to avoid becoming invisible.

- At Farm Journal, they are observing this shift in real-time and advise that an "answer-driven content strategy" and amplifying trusted voices will be more important than ever for ag marketers.

- Discoverability is now about ensuring your expertise, content, and brand authority surface at the exact moment your audience is looking for answers, across all channels where they're searching.

- In the AEO era, discoverability is about winning the citation, brand mention, and trusted source reference that builds authority, even in "zero-click" moments.

The article emphasizes the need for ag marketers to reevaluate their 2026 strategies to adapt to this evolving landscape of agricultural information discovery.

items.title: Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land
items.description: Also called agroforestry, forest farming is a great way to work within your environmental parameters and utilize the tree canopy to produce more for your farm. Especially for those who live in forested areas, this practice enhances farm output without compromising the ecosystem. The post Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
It originated in Brazil's tropical rainforests and involves integrating small-scale farming with conventional forestry to create a self-sustaining, ecologically-balanced system.

The most common forest farming method is thinning a forest to allow the best conditions for crops to grow in the understory, such as native ornamentals, fungi, fruit, timber, and forest food crops. Other approaches include silvopasture (combining forestry and ranching) and alley cropping (using tree canopies to protect specialty crops).

Benefits of forest farming include improved water and soil quality, increased carbon storage (up to 22 lbs per year), better temperature regulation, and the ability to grow specialized crops that thrive in forested environments. It supports biodiversity by providing habitat for beneficial insects, birds, mammals, fungi, and microbes.

Existing forested land, riparian areas, and even small amounts of forest on a farm can be suitable for conversion to an agroforestry system. Before starting, farmers should inventory their natural resources, manage any invasive trees, and develop a forest management plan with help from extension services.

Marketing forest crops often requires being proactive, as they may not fit typical farmer's market or restaurant sales channels. Options include online sales, agritourism, pick-your-own, and direct marketing associations. Regulations around wild-harvested plants also need to be considered.

items.title: Getting Started with Spray Drones in Iowa: A Practical Guide
items.description: Spray drones are increasingly being evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application. When used appropriately, these systems can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce fi
items.summary:
Summary:

Spray drones are increasingly being evaluated by Iowa farmers as a tool for crop input application. When used properly, they can provide flexibility, reduce field traffic, and improve access to hard-to-reach areas. However, adopting spray drone technology requires careful consideration of regulations, training, insurance, and management practices.

Key Points:
- Farmers should identify specific challenges they are trying to address with spray drones, such as making applications on wet soils, applying to tall crops, reducing compaction, or supplementing existing spraying capacity.
- Regulatory requirements include an FAA Part 107 Remote Pilot Certificate, FAA Part 137 Certification for aerial pesticide application, and Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship (IDALS) licensing.
- Insurance needs include chemical liability, general liability, and hull/physical damage coverage. Providers typically require FAA Part 137 certification.
- Equipment selection factors include spray tank capacity, battery life, nozzle options, and GPS guidance features.
- Proper training is essential for safe and effective operation, including calibration, weather monitoring, and maintenance.
- Farmers are encouraged to start on a limited scale, comparing results to conventional methods, before expanding adoption.
- Resources available include Iowa State University programs, the Digital Agriculture Innovation Lab, licensed dealers, and IDALS.
- Ongoing technology improvements in areas like payload, automation, and data integration will shape the long-term role of spray drones.

A 2-day FAA Part 107 training workshop is scheduled at the Digital Ag Innovation Lab in Ames, IA on February 24-25, 2026. The registration link is provided.

items.title: The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow
items.description: For farms in colder areas, starting seeds in time for the spring market requires a significant amount of time and indoor space. Winter sowing is a method that can be done outdoors and gives seedlings a stronger constitution as they mature. Here, we share plants that thrive when winter sown. The post The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow

Farmers can maximize profits and productivity in spring by adding winter sowing to their routine. This method involves starting hardy annuals and perennials in reused containers like milk jugs or plastic bags, which are placed outdoors to take advantage of the cold, moist conditions of winter.

Vegetables:
- Cabbages, including standard and Napa varieties, as well as the shorter-maturing 'Carex' type, thrive in cold weather.
- Spinach, especially mildew-resistant 'Avon' and bolt-resistant 'Space' varieties, does well with winter sowing.
- Bulbing onions, as well as bunching onions and shallots, can be started now based on your latitude (long-day, short-day, or intermediate-day onions).
- Leafy greens like kale, collards, chard, watercress, and microgreens are excellent winter sow candidates.

Flowers:
- Perennial flowers like pansies, echinacea, snapdragons, larkspur, and scabiosa can be winter sown to provide natural pest control and cut flowers.
- Pansies are hardy, colorful, and sell well as bedding plants or cut flowers.
- Echinacea needs cold stratification, which the winter sowing method provides.
- Snapdragons, in four different groups, can be selected based on your climate to ensure early maturity.
- Larkspur offers rare true-blue blooms and attracts pollinators.
- Scabiosa, or pincushion flowers, are lovely in arrangements and also attract beneficial insects.

By taking advantage of winter sowing, farmers can get a head start on their spring gardens and enjoy earlier harvests and blooms.

items.title: 2026 Crop Advantage Series Meetings to Be Held at 12 Locations in January
items.description: AMES, Iowa ‚Äì The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will take place at 12 locations across the state Jan. 6‚Äì29. Each meeting will feature tailored topics selected based on local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.
items.summary:
The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will be held at 12 locations across Iowa from January 6-29, 2026. The meetings are organized by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach to provide farmers and crop production professionals with the latest research-based information to help them make informed decisions for the upcoming growing season.

Key details:
- Dates and locations: Jan 6 (Sioux Center), Jan 7 (Storm Lake), Jan 8 (Burlington), Jan 9 (Mason City), Jan 13 (Estherville), Jan 15 (Waterloo), Jan 16 (Davenport), Jan 21 (Ankeny), Jan 22 (Atlantic), Jan 27 (Iowa City), Jan 28 (Le Mars), Jan 29 (Carroll)
- Early-bird registration is $75 until the week before each meeting, late/on-site registration is $100
- Registration includes refreshments, lunch, certified crop advisor credits, and access to resources
- Private pesticide applicator recertification is available for a $30 fee
- Topics include crop market and climate outlooks, nitrates and drinking water, profitable nutrient management, southern rust, transition planning, robots and drones, and more
- The goal is to help producers manage potential issues by sharing the latest scientific knowledge from Iowa State researchers
- Contact crops@iastate.edu or your regional ISU Extension agronomist for more information

items.title: Purdue field day to feature research on sorghum‚Äôs value as a forage crop
items.description: Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on Sept. 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center (FPAC) in Bedford, Indiana.
items.summary:
Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on September 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center in Bedford, Indiana. Interested participants should register by September 5.

The event will feature research on the value of sorghum as a forage crop compared to corn. Key highlights:

- Sorghum is more drought-tolerant and has lower nitrogen requirements than corn, and it is not a host for the tar spot pathogen.
- Agronomy experts like Mitch Tuinstra will share plant breeding techniques to improve sorghum yield and quality.
- Other speakers include Brad Shelton, Jason Tower, Nick Minton, and Jeff Jackson.
- Venue tours will be available from 3-5 pm and 6-8 pm, and a dinner and bull test station tour will be held from 5-6 pm.

This event aims to provide farmers with information on the potential benefits of using sorghum as a forage crop. Participants are encouraged to register by the September 5 deadline.

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July. Responses to the individual questi
items.summary:
The Purdue/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, while the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100 and the Index of Future Expectations rose 7 points to 119. 

This positive shift was attributed to fewer respondents reporting worsened conditions compared to a year ago and a decrease in those expecting negative future outcomes. However, high input costs (34%) and risk of lower crop/livestock prices (29%) remained the top concerns for farmers.

The Farm Financial Performance Index dropped 4 points in July to 81, 6 points lower than July 2023. This reflected farmers' worries about weakening commodity prices and high input costs. 

The Farm Capital Investment Index rose 6 points to 38 in July, though it remains 7 points lower than a year prior. This was due to a decrease in the number of producers who believe it's a bad time to make large investments, from 80% in June to 75% in July.

The Short-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index improved slightly to 118, while the Long-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index dropped 6 points to 146. About 72% of crop farmers expect cash rental rates to remain roughly the same in 2025 compared to 2024.

The Purdue University Center for Commercial Agriculture and CME Group conducted the survey from July 15-19, 2024. The barometer's principal investigator is James Mintert of Purdue.

items.title: Purdue researchers adopt interdisciplinary approach to assessing emerging tar spot disease in corn
items.description: For more than a century, tar spot fungal disease in corn kept its distance from the U.S., biding its time
items.summary:
The fungal disease has spread from Latin America to 16 U.S. states and Ontario, Canada since first being detected in the U.S. in 2015. 

The research team, led by C.D. Cruz, is using a mix of statistical analysis, data science, epidemiology, microbiology, artificial intelligence, and computer vision to better understand the dynamics of tar spot. Their work is funded by two USDA grants totaling nearly $1.1 million.

Key aspects of the research include:
- Developing a digital method to quantify tar spot using an algorithm that can detect and classify disease symptoms in 2 seconds.
- Integrating drone imagery, weather data, and traditional disease evaluations to build AI models that can detect and track tar spot.
- Characterizing tar spot epidemics at different scales using disease observations and drone data.

The interdisciplinary nature of the project, involving experts from agriculture and engineering, aims to provide rapid, accurate information to stakeholders and tackle the biosecurity challenges posed by this emerging disease. Collaborators include researchers in Colombia, Mexico, Ecuador, South Korea, and the U.S.

items.title: ISA will host sheep-themed educational opportunities and competitions at Indiana State Fair
items.description: In addition to 4-H and open sheep shows, the Indiana Sheep Association (ISA) is sponsoring sheep-themed competitions, vendors and educational opportunities at this year‚Äôs Indiana State Fair, with additional support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN SW).
items.summary:
The Indiana Sheep Association (ISA), with additional support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN S&W), is hosting a variety of sheep-themed events and competitions at the 2024 Indiana State Fair:

- The Wool and Ewe Room and Ewe2 boutique will be open throughout the fair, offering fairgoers Indiana-grown wool items, livestock- and country-themed products.
- On August 2nd at 10 a.m., there will be an open wool judging and wool sale event in the Blue Ribbon Pavilion.
- The Make It With Wool (MIWW) competition and fashion show will take place on August 4th at 2 p.m. in the Indiana Arts Building.
- The Indiana State Fair Shearing Contest will be held on August 4th at 5 p.m. in the Ball State University Champions Pavilion.
- Taste from Indiana Farms event, featuring free samples of Indiana lamb, will run from August 8-11 from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. in the Indiana Farm Bureau Fall Creek Pavilion.
- The Sheep to Shawl competition, where youth teams create a wool shawl from scratch in 4 hours, will be on August 18th at 10 a.m. in the Indiana Arts Building.
- Sheep can be seen in the Blue Ribbon Pavilion for open and 4-H shows from August 4-20.

The ISA is focused on showcasing the "Art and Nature" theme of sheep, featuring artwork from Indiana artists. One artist, Laura Winslow, donated copies of her sheep paintings that will be printed into stickers and magnets for distribution.

The Indiana Sheep Association was originally founded in 1876 as the Indiana Wool Growers Association, with the goal of promoting lamb and wool in the state and educating the community about the value of sheep and the industry. The IN S&W program supports educational, promotional, and research efforts related to sheep in Indiana, funded by a 0.5% checkoff on the net market price of each sheep sold.

items.title: Purdue Extension to present engaging art and nature demonstrations at Indiana State Fair
items.description: The Indiana State Fair kicks off Aug. 2 and highlights the theme ‚ÄúThe Art Nature of Fun‚Äù in collaboration with Newfields. Fairgoers will have the opportunity to speak with Purdue University representatives about agricultural and nature-related topics, which are available year-round through Purdue Extension.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- The Indiana State Fair will be held from August 2 to August 18, 2024, with the theme "The Art & Nature of Fun" in collaboration with Newfields.
- Purdue Extension will have a presence at the fair, offering interactive demonstrations and activities at the Purdue Extension Building on topics such as block play, financial management, entomology, forestry, and animal sciences.
- The Food Science Department will host an activity called "What's Growing on My Spinach?" to explore food microbiology and food safety, and will also offer samples of "Cricket Rice Krispies Treats."
- Seed art will be showcased in the livestock barns and the Purdue Extension Building, visually representing the fair's theme and providing educational information about the animals and agricultural topics.
- The Purdue Ag Alumni Association will sponsor the Pioneer Village, which will transport fairgoers to the 1800s and offer activities like antique tractors, a farm toy show, and a fiddler's contest.
- Purdue Extension exhibits will be located throughout the fairgrounds, spanning various buildings and pavilions.
- Purdue University is a public research institution with over 105,000 students, and it is committed to affordability and accessibility, having frozen tuition for 13 years.

items.title: Potassium Cycle now available!
items.description: Check out the new NPM publication! This two-page publication gives a visual overview of the potassium cycle as it relates to general Wisconsin cropping systems, and on the second page, outlines some key potassium concepts …
items.summary: The University of Wisconsin-Madison has released a new publication called "Potassium Cycle" that provides a visual overview of the potassium cycle in Wisconsin cropping systems. The two-page publication outlines key potassium concepts and recommendations for specific situations. The publication is available for download only and was released on June 12, 2024. Farmers can access and download the publication from the UW Madison website.

items.title: Wisconsin Winter Wheat Update
items.description: Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, University of Wisconsin-Madison Winter wheat in Wisconsin continues to move through growth stages at record pace. We are about 10-14 days …
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Wisconsin winter wheat is 10-14 days ahead of normal growth stages due to a warm spring and timely rain.
- There is a high likelihood of stripe rust disease appearing in Wisconsin this season, though it has not been detected yet. Farmers are advised to scout for it.
- Fusarium head blight (FHB) is also a concern this season, as the moderate temperatures and adequate precipitation create favorable conditions. FHB can limit yields and produce the mycotoxin deoxynivalenol (DON or vomitoxin), which can lead to grain being discounted or rejected if levels exceed 2 ppm.
- Farmers are encouraged to monitor for these diseases and take appropriate in-season management actions.

The article was posted on May 20, 2024 by Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, and Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, from the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

items.title: Questions to consider prior to replanting a soybean field
items.description: Shawn P. Conley, Soybean and Small Grains Specialist, UW-Madison Early in the growing season, abiotic (freezing temperatures, hail, flooding, etc.) and biotic (slugs, deer, disease, insects, etc.) factors often reduce soybean plant stands. A soybean …
items.summary:
The key points from the article are:

- Early in the growing season, soybean fields can experience stand losses due to various factors like freezing temperatures, hail, flooding, pests, etc.

- Soybean plants can compensate for open spaces by developing axillary branches and yielding well even with lower plant populations.

- Action is warranted if stand loss leaves fewer than 50,000-60,000 evenly-distributed plants per acre in southern regions, or 75,000 plants per acre in northern regions, or if there are areas over 6-10 sq ft without any plants.

- Factors to consider when deciding whether to replant include: existing stand and distribution, calendar date and delayed planting effects, weed management, seed/variety availability, cost, and yield penalty of delayed replanting.

- The article provides a link to a more detailed fact sheet on soybean replant decisions.

items.title: Spraying 2,4-D on Soybean in 2024?
items.description: Daniel H. Smith, Outreach Program Manager, UW-Madison Division of Extension, Rodrigo Werle, Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist, UW-Madison Are you planning to spray 2,4-D for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybean? The 2,4-D …
items.summary:
The key points from the agricultural news article are:

- Farmers planning to spray 2,4-D for post-emergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybeans can only use the 2,4-D choline formulation found in Enlist One and Enlist Duo herbicides. Other 2,4-D ester or amine formulations cannot be used post-emergence in Enlist E3 soybeans.

- There have been reports of producers, agronomists, and even Certified Crop Advisors considering using the ester or amine formulations post-emergence, which is not allowed by the label.

- For burndown applications, if using a 2,4-D ester or amine formulation product, there is a soybean plant back interval of at least 7 days when using 0.5 lbs ae/acre. This restriction does not apply if using Enlist One or Enlist DUO.

- The article was posted on May 11, 2024 by Daniel H. Smith from the UW-Madison Division of Extension and Rodrigo Werle, a Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist at UW-Madison.

- The key message is that farmers must follow the herbicide label requirements, as the label is the law.

items.title: Wisconsin CCA Board Election Results
items.description: Thank you to everyone who provided nominations and voted in the recent Wisconsin CCA Board election. On-behalf of the election process I would like to welcome Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura to the …
items.summary:
The University of Wisconsin-Madison Division of Extension has announced the results of the Wisconsin Certified Crop Adviser (WI CCA) Board election. Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura have been elected to the WI CCA Board and will serve two, three-year terms.

All Wisconsin CCAs in good standing are eligible for nomination and can vote in future elections, which will be held again in early 2025. Daniel H. Smith, the Outreach Program Manager for the Crops and Soils Program at the University of Wisconsin-Madison Division of Extension, thanked everyone who provided nominations and voted in the recent election.
